description: From Middle English raven, reven, from Old English hræfn, from Proto-West Germanic *hrabn, from  Proto-Germanic *hrabnaz (“raven”), from Proto-Indo-European *ḱrep-, from Proto-Indo-European *ḱer- (“to croak, crow”).

entries.meaning: Of the color of the raven; jet-black
examples: She was a tall, sophisticated, raven-haired beauty.

entries.meaning: (countable) Any of several, generally large and lustrous black species of birds in the genus Corvus, especially the common raven, Corvus corax.

description: From Middle English ravene, ravine, from Old French raviner (“rush, seize by force”), itself from ravine (“rapine”), from Latin rapīna (“plundering, loot”), itself from rapere (“seize, plunder, abduct”).

entries.meaning: Prey; plunder; food obtained by violence.

verbs.description: raven (third-person singular simple present ravens, present participle ravening, simple past and past participle ravened)

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To obtain or seize by violence.

examples: The raven is both a scavenger, who ravens a dead animal almost like a vulture, and a bird of prey, who commonly ravens to catch a rodent.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To show rapacity; to be greedy (for something).
examples: […]  because hogs are commonly rauening for their meat, more then other cattel, it is meet therefore to haue them ringed, or else they wil doe much hurt in digging and turning vp corne fieldes  […]
